author: Rebecca Rosenberg
title: White supremacist pelted with threats by angry prisoners | New York Post
text:
The white supremacist charged with killing a black man in Manhattan last week was pelted with angry curses and threats by other prisoners Monday as he was walked into a courtroom to be presented with an indictment for first-degree murder as an act of terrorism. 
The audible chorus of anger carried into the court after a door separating the room from holding pens opened and James Harris Jackson emerged, flanked on both sides by court officers.
SEE ALSO 
White supremacist killed black man for a 'rush' 0:0 The Baltimore white supremacist who came to the Big Apple... Jackson, 28, insisted on appearing in court to face the judge instead of letting his defense lawyer waive the appearance for the stabbing death of Timothy Caughman on March 20. 
The bigot​, who told cops he came up here from Baltimore for the express purpose of killing a black man on the streets of New York,​ showed no emotion as Assistant District Attorney Joan Illuzzi-Orbon read the charges.
Jackson faces first​-​ and second-degree murder as an act of terrorism, second-degree murder as a hate crime and three counts of weapons possession.
Caughman’s friends watched from the gallery, many of them weeping. “Tim Caughman did not deserve to die like that,” said a tearful Portia Clark, of Ozone Park, who knew him for over 55 years.
Manhattan District Attorney Cyrus Vance Jr. condemned the shocking murder in a statement. “James Jackson prowled the streets of New York for three days in search of a black person to assassinate in order to launch a campaign of terrorism against our Manhattan community and the values we celebrate,” Vance Jr. said.
“Last week, with total presence of mind, he acted on his plan, randomly selecting a beloved New Yorker solely on the basis of his skin color, and stabbing him r​​epeatedly and publicly,” the statement continues. “ James Jackson wanted to kill black men, planned to kill black men, and then did kill a black man.”
SEE ALSO 
White supremacist wanted to recruit racists for Times Square slaughter 0:0 The sword-wielding white supremacist accused of killing a black man... Vance said that the hate-spewing army veteran chose Midtown to commit his crime to maximize media exposure.
Harris allegedly saw Caughman, a can collector, stooped over a garbage can and stabbed him repeatedly with an 18-inch sword on 36th Street between Eighth and Ninth avenues.
The mortally wounded Caughman, 66, stumbled into the Midtown South precinct shortly before he died.
Two days later, Jackson turned himself into cops, telling them “You need to arrest me,” according to a criminal complaint.
Caughman had ditched his sword earlier but had two other knives on him when apprehended.
He told authorities he came to New York “for the purpose of killing black men and had stalked numerous potential victims” court papers allege.
Jackson took particular exception to “black men mixing with white men” the papers state.
If convicted of the top count, he faces life in prison without parole.
